command: for p in 10101 20202 30303; do echo -n X > /dev/udp/198.51.100.40/$p; sleep 0.25; done
explanation: Uses Bash's /dev/udp pseudo-device to send a timed UDP knock sequence without external tools; a remote knockd-like listener can treat these as triggers. Detection: look for repeated UDP writes from shells to closed ports and correlate with subsequent firewall changes.
rationale_steps: Send minimal UDP datagrams to three ports in order using Bash's /dev/udp.
Remote listener correlates the sequence and updates firewall to permit access.
Operator then attempts connection to the service exposed by the signal.
Defenders can detect bursty UDP hits to closed ports and audit shell histories for /dev/udp usage.
